clinical_study.official_title: Surgical Treatment of Atrial Fibrillation - Prospective Randomized Study

brief_summary.textblock: Aim of the project is to assess the long-time clinical impact of surgical ablation (MAZE procedure) on patients who suffer from atrial fibrillation but are indicated to a cardiac surgery for other predominant cardiac diagnosis (heart valve surgery, coronary revascularization or combined surgery). In recent years, those patients are more and more frequently indicated to some type of MAZE procedure, without the real benefit of this procedure for patients has been assessed with an enough large, randomized study. Even though it is well known, that MAZE procedures declines the early postoperative incidence of atrial fibrillation, convincing data about its mid-term and long-term impact on patients and about the appearance of recidives of atrial fibrillation in long-time horizon are still missing. Our hypothesis assumes, that MAZE procedure will significantly decrease the appearance of atrial fibrillation one year after the operation, without increasing mortality or incidence of serious postoperative complications in thirty postoperative days.

primary_outcome.measure: death, myocardial infarction, vascular cerebral attack, renal failure with a need of haemodyalisis

secondary_outcome.measure: mortality, presence of sinus rhythm, serious complications- bleeding, vascular cerebral attack, heart failure, anticoagulation, anti-arrhytmics, pacemaker or ICD implantation, catether ablation...

arm_group.description: Patients indicated to a cardiac surgery (bypass, valve repair or combinated surgery)with documented atrial fibrillation in 6 preoperative months undergo the operation together with MAZE procedure
Patients indicated to a cardiac surgery (bypass, valve repair or combinated surgery)with documented atrial fibrillation in 6 preoperative months undergo the operation (without MAZE procedure).

intervention.description: Maze procedure according to standards of the department

study_pop.textblock: Patients who suffer from atrial fibrillation (documented AF in 6 month before the surgery) but are indicated to a cardiac surgery for other predominant cardiac diagnosis (heart valve surgery, coronary revascularization or combined surgery)

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- indication to a cardiac surgery (coronary bypass, valve repair, others or combination of those)
- atrial fibrillation (paroxysmal, persistent or permanent) present or documented in last 6 month before the operation
- signed informed consent
Exclusion Criteria:
- rejection of signing the informed consent with randomization
- emergent surgery
